title: Scientists Discover a Cause of Lupus, Possible Way to Reverse It (northwestern.edu)
first_paragraph: Northwestern Medicine and Brigham and Women’s Hospital scientists have discovered a molecular defect that promotes the pathologic immune response in systemic lupus erythematosus (known as lupus) and in a study published in Nature, show that reversing this defect may potentially reverse the disease.

title: Show HN: Dut, a fast Linux disk usage calculator (codeberg.org)
first_paragraph: By default, dut will output a tree of the biggest directories it finds under your current directory.

title: Brian Kernighan on "The Practice of Programming" [video] (youtube.com)
Real-time audio programming 101: time waits for nothing (rossbencina.com)
first_paragraph: “The audio processing thread is stalling because the client’s implementation of some XAudio2 callback is doing things that can block the thread, such as accessing the disk, synchronizing with other threads, or calling other functions that may block. Such tasks should be performed by a lower-priority background thread that the callback can signal.”

title: Ed Stone, Top Scientist–and Salesman–For the Voyager Mission, Dies at 88 (wsj.com)
An analysis of module names inside top PyPI packages (joshcannon.me)
first_paragraph:
Naming is important (as well as hard). Good names are good. Bad names are… bad.
And we name a lot of things. In Python (a name) code is bundled and uploaded as a package 
(another name), usually to the Python Package Index (PyPI, a third name). Inside of these
packages is code. Most commonly, Python code (but they truly can contain anything
(like whole books).
The only relationship between the package name and the module name(s) is the same as the 
relationship between a cat’s name and its demeanor. Usually “fluffy” is a fluffy cat,
but it’s a convention. “Cupcake” could be the name of a very very naughty kitten.
